title.narrative: Indonesia: Affiliate transition

description.narrative:
Goal: Oxfam in Indonesia will transition into an affiliate organization that is leading on Inequality and Local Humanitarian Leadership in Indonesia and the wider Asia region.
Outputs: 1. Strategic development towards affiliation Oxfam Indonesia will have an independent position within the confederation upon completion of the affiliation process. The office aims to support local organizations to increase their presence by making use of the network of the confederation. The voice of Indonesian citizens and CSOs can be included in Oxfam’s advocacy and influencing work. The Indonesia office can work through networks in the region to work on influencing and advocacy.
2. Thought leadership and Knowledge Management Oxfam Indonesia will focus on advocacy work on Covid-19 and on inequality. It will establish a Knowledge Management System that can be used within the organization as well as by partner organizations. The office will support and strengthen partners’ influencing work in the humanitarian sector through the (already existing) network of SEJAJAR. This network, with now over 600 organizations, was established with two partners when Covid-19 hit the country in March 2020, to build collaborations and encourage dialogue and advocacy on Covid-19. Oxfam Indonesia will also conduct organizational learning and training, with due attention for safeguarding policies and practices in programs.
3. Partnership Academy Oxfam plans to invest in a strong partnership model that will act as a hub for a global network of partners and allies, with or without resources. ThePartnership Academy will serve to support current partner organizations to develop their organization in the area of good governance, risk management, policy development, influencing and hard skills in development and humanitarian work. This is part of Oxfam’s own exit strategy, from an Oxfam in Indonesia country office to Oxfam Indonesia, as an independent new Oxfam affiliate.

participating-org.narrative:
Novib in 1994 became a member of Oxfam International. A group of twelve independent, like-minded development organizations strivingfor a fairer world.
Oxfam's work with a total of 3,000 partner organizations in 100 countries. They maintain contacts with severalmajor international networks and civil society organizations. The collaboration began with advocacy but also extends to the projectwork and joint campaigning and relief.
One of the members of Oxfam International, Oxfam GB, an independent British organization. Oxfam GB works with volunteers, donors. Oxfam GB has an office in Jakarta.

title.narrative: CO-Drought Effected People Response (RR

description.narrative: In response to the current water and food shortages caused by the ‘triple threat’ of drought, locust and COVID-19 in Eastern Somaliland, Oxfam and local partner Taakulo will support 43,800 rural IDPs and host communities (pastoralists) with integrated WASH and Food Security interventions in the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions. The WASH component will reach over 43,800 people with clean drinking water and an improved and safe access to rehabilitated water sources. Existing water market structures will be sustainably strengthened through Cash for Water interventions and water prices prevented from rising by solarizing water sources and providing operators with the means to maintain existing desalination units. 1,036 households ( 6,216 women, men, boys and girls) will be supported through the food security and livelihoods assistance component. The Sida RRM will contribute to addressing the immediate food needs of the people affected by drought and the socioeconomic impact of COVID-19. Oxfam and Taakulo will respond through cash assistance that allows households to meet their basic food needs. Community and government engagement will be at the centre of the response and close engagement is ensured during the project design and implementation stages as this will increase ownership and social accountability, and ensure sustainability after our intervention ends.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

title.narrative: DECP COVID-19 support to ZFE Zambia in 2020
Yangon Port Development

description.narrative: Based on the congestion/limitations of the old city port and the existing Thilawa port and taken into account the growing transport needs to cater for domestic purposes and trade to West China, it is expected that the city ports and the actual Yangon river navigation capacity will reach its limits by 2027-2030 (depending on COVID-19 recovery). The Yangon Region Government (YRG) therefore intends to develop new port facilities towards the sea on the West Bank of the Yangon River. These new facilities are designated as a location to which the existing Yangon city ports are to be relocated (strategic objective), but will also provide necessary capacity and cost reduction on the short-term (as inner ports will be relocated gradually). By shifting the inner ports, the vessel turnaround time will be reduced as the port would be closer to the sea and the dredging expenses spending on inner shallow areas will be saved too. The map below provides an overview of the port locations in Yangon, indicating the two current port locations (City Port Area and Thilawa Port) and the intended relocation of the City Port Area (New West Bank Port).

title.narrative: WASH Officer UNHCR Cameroon (DSS220CM01)

description.narrative: WASH Officer UNHCR Cameroon – Supporting the provision of WASG services to persons of concern to UNHCR. This includes ensuring that an adequate level of water service is provided at each site in accordance with applicable UNHCR and National Standard and in line with addressing the global Covid-19 pillars of activities in regard to (1) risk communication and community engagement – WASH awareness and hygiene promotion, (2) infection prevention and control – access to adequate WASH services to institutions and households, (3) operational support and logistics – ensure enough contingency stocks according to standards.

title.narrative: MHPSS Specialist Lebanon UNICEF

description.narrative: On 4th of August 2020, two explosions hit the city of Beirut, which killed more than 200 people and injured over 4000 people. Lebanon had already been suffering from political instability, economic collapse and a surge in COVID-19 cases. These multi-faceted disasters have a devastating and profound impact on the lives and wellbeing of the population and there is therefore an urgent need for reinforced capacity and resources to enable coordinated multi-sectoral MHPSS response to the varying and complex mental health and psychosocial needs of children, adolescents and families.

title.narrative: MHPSS Consultant Peru WHO

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Consultant in Peru for WHO will be to work with technical UN programmes, PAHO Country Offices and Ministers of Health in prioritized countries in the region, to achieve the best attainable health status for the populations that are affected by COVID-19. The following countries have been mapped as priority for this project: Peru, Haïti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Guatemala, Bolivia and Ecuador.

title.narrative: MHPSS Expert Pakistan WHO

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Consultant in Pakistan for WHO is to support the Technical Working Group on MHPSS and specifically with the coordination with ministries, INGOs and NGOs. The consultant will have the overall responsibility for coordinating operations to ensure the timely delivery, effective and efficient implementation of the activities, to achieve the best attainable mental health and psychosocial well-being status for the populations that are affected by COVID-19

title.narrative: MHPSS Officer COVID-19 Interagency TWGs in the African Region

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Officer COVID-19 Interagency TWGs in the African Region will be to provide technical support to francophone countries in Africa to strengthen the coordination of the MHPSS response and supporting the interagency MHPSS Technical Working Groups.

title.narrative: MHPSS specialist COVID emergency Haiti (WHO/PAHO)

description.narrative: As part of the WHO/PAHO Regional project to support countries to strengthen and scale up their MHPSS response capacity, the MHPSS Capacity Building Expert for Haiti will support the two Mental Health coordinators nominated by the Ministry of Health of Haiti to establish a MHPSS coordination mechanism.This project has the following objectives:Objective 1: Strengthen national capacities to coordinate and provide quality MHPSS to communities affected by the COVID-19 pandemicObjective 2: Develop and adapt communication materials related to MHPSSObjective 3: Strengthen the capacity of health professionals, frontline workers, health managers and decision makers to deliver effective MHPSS responses to the COVID-19 pandemic within and beyond the health systemPAHO will seek partnerships on both operational and technical levels with national and international non-governmental organizations, WHO/PAHO collaborating centers, academia and the Red Cross in order to enhance the Project’s impact on populations.

title.narrative: Towards a new port development strategy for Indonesia

description.narrative: The Indonesian Ministry of Transport (MoT) and Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs (Menko Maritim) are in an immediate need for support to overcome the challenges they face in the port sector. Indonesian counterparts of the Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management need to rethink various aspects of port development strategies in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis. The organization of a series of webinars, followed by the jointly development strategy document, would greatly support the Indonesian challenges

title.narrative: Safe Trade Emergency Program Mozambique

description.narrative: Safe Trade Emergency Program for Mozambique (STEPMOZ) mitigates the short-term COVID-19 crisis by making trade safer at two key border points, between Mozambique and Malawi, along the Beira Corridor. This responds to demand from the Government of Mozambique and private sector partners to keep the road borders and corridors open.

title.narrative: Support to financial monitoring system, Pakistan

description.narrative: The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) is an intergovernmental organization to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism. The objectives of FATF are to set standards and promote effective implementation of legal, regulatory and operational measures to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism, to protect the integrity of the international financial system.Pakistan is still on the grey-list of the FATF also after the latest assessment in October 2020. a new assessment will take place to judge whether the country should be blacklisted. This situation harms the business climate of the country and has a negative impact on the financial crisis Pakistan is currently in. Therefore, this project aims to support the FMU (directly) and the Ministry of Commerce of Pakistan (indirectly) and therewith the financial sector via knowledge exchange with the Dutch Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU-NL), in order to comply with the criteria set by the FATF and be able to move to the white list. FIU-NL has valuable expertise that can assist FMU Pakistan in improving its way of working and thereby supporting Pakistan in reforming its financial system and implementing FATF criteria and recommendations. Their knowledge will be shared via remote assistance to FMU and a study visit of FMU and TAMLIT to the FIU-NL in the Netherlands, if the COVID situation allows.

title.narrative: ILO Decent work textile VN MY

description.narrative: The ILO project, lasting two to three years (2021-2023), aims to support the Governments of Viet Nam and Myanmar in skills forecasting and skills development. It should prevent the textiles and clothing industries in Asia to revert to business as usual after the COVID-19 crisis. The society must build back better and invest in more resilient, inclusive and sustainable sectors and societies. In the textiles and clothing industries, which were already undergoing a rapid and profound digital and robotics transformation, skills development and forecasting are key to helping employers and workers navigate an uncertain future and to advancing decent and sustainable work.This funding concerns an ILO project with a total project budget of 650,000 US Dollar, with contribution of:• RVO: 400,000 Euro (480,000 US Dollar);• ILO/Japan Fund for Building Social Safety Nets in Asia and the Pacific: 100,000 US Dollar, and • National governments: 70,000 US Dollar in kind.

title.narrative: Online Poultry Seminar Democratic Republic Congo

description.narrative: The study ‘Increasing self-sufficiency in poultry meat and egg production in Kinshasa’ was carried out by WUR in 2018 and because of the political situation in DRC and COVID not much follow up could be given in 2019 and 2020. In Q1 of 2021 an online event on the study will be organized with local stakeholders as well as Dutch participants.The goal is a wider dissemination of the results and conclusions of the study, creating a platform for stakeholders of the poultry industry in the DRC to discuss the possibilities to further develop the sector, identifying opportunities for the private sector as well as recommendations for the public sector in order to support the development of the poultry sector and by connecting Congolese actors to the expertise of the Dutch poultry sector.

title.narrative: Rural connectivity for the young: support to Hosts for Peace project in Nariño and Putumayo, Colombia

description.narrative: The implementation of the Peace Agreement with FARC in Colombia is supported by the Netherlands through political and financial commitment via the European Union Trust Fund for Peace (EUTF). The multiannual plan of the Embassy supports the implementation of the Comprehensive Rural Reform to strengthen local economies (training, agricultural production chains and access to markets) of communities affected in the internal conflict in Colombia. The project complements the ongoing Host for Peace project that is being implemented by ICCO cooperation with support of the EUTF to offer vocational training and support business initiatives in the Putumayo and Nariño regions; two of the most affected regions of the internal conflict in Colombia.. The project enables rural connectivity and ensures the continuity and finalization of the training in entrepreneurship (gastronomy and tourism) of 262 rural young Afro-Colombian women through an inclusive business model during the COVID-19 pandemic crisis that doesn’t allow presential training due to the lock down measures. The project leads to the further development of micro and small businesses by increasing the affordable offer of internet in remote areas of these regions.

title.narrative: Chamber of Commerce Training of Trainers

description.narrative: The Federation of Palestinian Chambers of Commerce, Industry and Agriculture (FPCCIA) based in Ramallah is piloting the founding of an ‘ICU unit’ to help MSMEs which are negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The ICU unit will provide MSMEs with technical assistance. For the pilot, 20 MSMEs have been selected and the major areas of improvement have been identified in a study. Through RVO’s support, 18 trainers (one from each Palestinian Chamber of Commerce, which are members of FPCCIA) will be trained on four topics of improvement, so that they can support the MSMEs as an ICU unit (training of trainers). The expert giving the training of trainers will also coach the selected 20 MSMEs in the pilot phase.

title.narrative: Scoping study healthcare Philippines

description.narrative: In 2019 the President of the Philippines signed the Universal Healthcare Act into law, kicking off what is supposed to be an ambitious overhaul of the Philippine healthcare system. In 2020 the COVID-19 pandemic hit the Philippines, exposing some of the shortcomings of the Philippine healthcare system in software, hardware and orgware. The starting point for this project is the current situation: how does the health care sector look like, who are the stakeholders, and what venues are there for potential cooperation between the Netherlands and the Philippines in the healthcare sector?This project will result in an analytical report on the sector, a road map with proposed follow-up actions for the embassy and two webinars for Dutch and Philippines stakeholders on the results of the study. This study should serve as the starting point for further development of local private healthcare parties with the ultimate goal of strengthening the Philippines healthcare sector.

title.narrative: Consumer behaviour & food safety poultry in Myanmar

description.narrative: This project is about the increase and the acceptance and food safety awareness and improve the reputation of professionally slaughtered and processed poultry meat among Myanmar consumers.In 2020, the first modern poultry slaughterhouse of Myanmar, with a capacity of 1,000 birds per hour, has been opened at the premises of Wai Yang Aung in Yangon. Allowing to meet the highest international standards in terms of hygiene, food safety, working conditions and animal welfare. However, Myanmar consumers are hard to convince to buy cooled or frozen poultry meat slaughtered at professional slaughterhouses instead of whole birds to be slaughtered at home or wet markets. Thus, the arrival of modern slaughterhouses does not automatically imply that consumers will shift towards buying these poultry products.Therefore, the poultry meat processors, retail chains and public stakeholders will be advised on the most promising marketing campaign approach, including an implementation roadmap, to boost the reputation of and the demand for hygienically slaughtered, processed, stored and transported poultry meat.The current COVID-19 pandemic and growing global attention for food safety offer a good momentum to initiate a shift in consumer behaviour.

title.narrative: Nexus Project Peru: NL-PE expert support for implementation of Santa Eulalia scoping mission water, energy and food security (WEF)

description.narrative: Peru, together with the Netherlands, are part of the UN High Level Panel on Water (HLWP) and both are convening countries of the Global Commission on Adaptation. The Water Energy and Food Security (WEF) nexus approach fit in the overall national and international policy ambitions of both countries to ensure efficient use of natural resources and solve climate change challenges.The project complements and facilitates the implementation of the scoping mission of the project “WEF Nexus in the Santa Eulalia river basin in Lima, Peru. This mission is implemented by Deltares (water), TNO (energy) and Wageningen University (food) in a digital format due to the travel restrictions imposed by the COVID 19 pandemic. The purpose of the scoping mission is to better understand the current situation in the Santa Eulalia river basin, to consult with the key stakeholders and to identify the current and future problems related to the water, agriculture and energy sectors. This to be able to formulate more precisely the objectives, scope and deliverables of the PSD WEF nexus study for Santa Eulalia river basin planned for 2021. The WEF project will help reduce and/or avoid potential trade-offs over the use of increasingly limited water (surface water and groundwater), energy, land and food resources and will promote a better management of these resources at the local, regional and national level.This project provides local and Dutch technical and operational support to the Netherlands embassy in Lima for a successful implementation of the digital scoping missions.

UNICEF ECHO HIP 2020

description.narrative: Au total, la population des communes de Les Anglais, Chardonnières et Tiburon qui bénéficiera des activités du projet sera les élèves de l’école-abri qui sera réhabilité, les personnes utilisant le point d’eau, les 75 volontaires qui seront formés pour appuyer la population en période d’urgence et la population qui sera hébergée dans l’abri en cas d’aléa.
Département du Sud. Communes de Chardonnières, Les Anglais, Tiburon

La CRNL travail en Haïti en étroite coordination avec la CR Haitienne (CRH) comme institution auxiliaire de l’état pour la préparation et la réponse aux urgences (voir coordination avec la DPC), et la Fédération International de la CR (FICR) ainsi que les autres Sociétés Nationales Participantes (SNP) présentes dans le pays. Dans le cadre de cet accord la CRNL s’engage à faciliter la coordination de l’UNICEF avec la CRH, afin d’organiser des activités de préparation et réponse aux urgences avec une couverture dans le Grand-Sud, en cas de nécessitée (ces dernières activités ne sont pas incluses dans le présent projet, mais pourront faire partie d’un accord de partenariat séparé).

L’expérience a démontré qu’Haïti est très vulnérable aux épidémies, en témoigne l’épidémie de choléra au cours de laquelle plus de 820 000 cas suspects ont été recensés entre 2010 et 2019 et qui a fait plus de 10 000 morts selon le MSPP. Cette pandémie de Covid-19 s’inscrit donc dans un contexte sanitaire déjà très précaire avec des conséquences potentiellement dramatiques pour la population haïtienne, particulièrement les ménages les plus vulnérables qui ont vu leur situation socio-économique et sanitaire se dégrader continuellement depuis le début de l’année 2018. Au niveau national, il n’y a que 26 sites de prise en charge de Covid-19 soit 1 011 lits pour recevoir les patients, pour une population de 11 millions d’habitants.
Projet d’amélioration des capacités de préparation et de réponse aux urgences des acteurs locaux et de la résilience des communautés face aux crises climatiques, sociales et épidémiologiques.

title.narrative: Covid-19 Response CAR

description.narrative: A project that aims to address the spread of COVID-19 in CAR through Health and WaSH measures.
Bangui

Contribute to the implementation of the national response plan to COVID-19 disease in the Central African Republic i.e. to reduce the risk of further spread of COVID-19 through risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) and health and hygiene promotion activities at epicentres of infection as prioritized by the Ministry of Health. This intervention will be undertaken primarily to cover 18 localities for the time being and for a period of 6 months, depending on the development of the pandemic in the country and the MoH priorities.
NLRC & CRCA

This operation will focus on RCCE through social mobilization, and promotion of positive health and hygiene practices through sensitisation campaigns, handwashing campaigns, surveillance or early referral activities, SGBV and psychosocial support, especially for DBM teams, health workers as well as the community. The Movement Coordination will support the CRCA to ensure effective participation of communities by providing information needs on COVID-19, setting up feedback mechanism as guided by the IFRC CEA standards and Core Humanitarian Standards (CHS). The approach for the risk communication will be done through the most effective and appropriate channels of communication with communities.

COVID-19 Preparedness and Response in Kassala and West Darfur, Sudan

description.narrative: Kassala and West Darfur, Sudan
Supported activities include health and hygiene promotion, community surveillance, communication and community engagement and small scale wash hardware.
The overall targeted beneficiaries for both states is 591,757.

The world is facing an unprecedented situation with the onset of the COVID-19 epidemic. In the global south, which already has poor public health outcomes, the potential impact on communities is catastrophic. People in Sudan have limited knowledge of COVID-19 and misconceptions and false information are being shared widely, including through social media. Severe restrictions, such as a full lockdown of movement outside of the home is challenging in Sudan as the economy is reliant on daily workers. Although placing extensive limitation of movement may assist to prevent the spread of COVID-19, it will likely mean food insecurity for a large proportion of the population and other high risk scenarios and unhealthy coping mechanisms. Preparing and responding to COVID-19 epidemic is further complicated in Sudan due to a declining economic and unstable political situation in-country, including ongoing protests, a new government, lack of basic commodities such as fuel and bread and increasing inflation.

This action will support Sudanese Red Crescent Society (SRCS) to implement their preparedness and response plan for COVID-19 in Kassala and West Darfur Branches, Sudan. The overall goal of SRCS is to contribute to the response to the COVID 19 outbreak by preventing human-to-human transmission of the virus caring for those affected in Sudan.

COVID-19 Response and Preparedness South Sudan

description.narrative: Activities included in this response focus on trainings of volunteers on WaSH and Health, hygiene promotion, improving access to safe water and public health awareness raising.
Juba, South Sudan

South Sudan can expect a massive impact within a matter of weeks if no effective measures are taken early in the COVID-19 outbreak, unless effective suppression and control measures are enacted in all areas with active outbreaks. The risk of further COVID-19 importation to South Sudan has been assessed to be high.
The overall targeted beneficiaries for this intervention is 85,000.

This intervention will support South Sudanese Red Cross (SSRC) to contribute to prevention of COVID-19 transmission in South Sudan’s main hub, Juba. The overall goal of SSRC is to contribute to the prevention and control of COVID-19 community transmission through increased knowledge among health care workers and Red Cross volunteers; and improved preventive COVID-19 hygiene behavior by the vulnerable population.

Covid-19 response activities of the Palestine Red Crescent Society in the occupied Palestinian Territory

description.narrative: Occupied Palestinian territory

On 31 December 2019, the Government of China reported a cluster of cases of pneumonia of unknown cause in Wuhan, Hubei Province. A novel corona virus was identified and has been named COVID-19. On 30 January, World Health Organization (WHO) declared the COVID-19 outbreak a public health emergency of international concern. On March 11, WHO declared the COVID-19 outbreak a pandemic.
As of 6th April, a total of 246 Palestinians have been confirmed to have COVID-19, 234 in the West Bank (excluding East Jerusalem Palestinians), and 12 in the Gaza Strip. Only one person died from COVID-19 on 25 March in the West Bank until April 6th . The majority of people do not present critical symptoms and 23 people have recovered. While the current number of people detected in the oPt remains low, this may reflect the limited testing capacity. Contact tracing has been initiated for all confirmed cases. (Source: WHO)
Although the Palestinian Authority (PA) has taken strict measures early enough, and was able to some extent to contain the situation and prevent rapid spread of it in the oPT, stopping at around 100 cases; the real challenge started when the Palestinians workers in Israel started coming back to oPT after the spread of COVID-19 where the cases so far are more than 7000. The total number of workers amount to more than 45000 worker, and the PA is struggling to receive them, making tests for them and ensure the quarantine measures are taking place; especially as the cases among them have started to increase in tens. The PA fears a widespread of COVID-19 in the oPT that cannot be dealt with, given the Palestinian MoH incapability of dealing with hundreds of cases due to the lack of the needed capacities in the available hospital, that would lead to a collapse in the health system in Palestine.
The capacities of the MoH as indicated in their latest report for WB and GZ include: a total of 375 ICU beds, and 295 ventilators only. Therefore, the Government of Palestine is taking the strictest measures at the earliest stages possible.
In light of the above, the Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas extended the State of Emergency in Palestine for 30 days starting April 6th. This was accompanied by stricter measures on the various levels, such as movement hours, testing cases, etc.
The number of cases continues to grow, and the threat of further spread within the region and globally remains high. The COVID-19 outbreak and response has been accompanied by a massive “infodemic” that makes it hard for people to find trustworthy sources and evidence-based guidance when they need it. Understanding of this virus and the resulting outbreak is rapidly evolving. Information gaps have led to misconceptions, stigmatization, rumours and uncertainty that are currently partially filled by speculation in scientific and public communities, contradicting evidence-based health information and, in extreme cases, stopping people from protecting themselves and undermining the correct health seeking behaviours.

PRCS COVID-19 Response will focus on the training of staff and volunteers; disseminating key public health messages through activating volunteers at a community level applying alternative approaches in lockdown situation, the use of social media, and protecting the EMS staff and volunteers through the provision of PPEs as well as the preparedness of various PRCS hospitals to be used as quarantine or even treatment centers in an advanced or complicated scenario. Relief and PSS activities will address areas not reached by other partners and target the most vulnerable communities.
As any pandemic, COVID-19 operations shall begin and end in communities; who shall be engaged and trained and prepared to a quick and easy spreading virus. Hence, PRCS relies on its long-standing policy and strategy of Decentralization and Resilience of communities. The added value of having the largest spread in the oPT through volunteers, branches and sub-branches will support the response plan operations of COVID-19. PRCS mobilizes all of its assets and human resources to achieve its objectives and reach the last mile.
Palestine Red Crescent Society in the occupied Palestinian territory and the Netherlands Red Cross

To ensure a rapid, efficient and coordinated response, the PRCS focuses on the following components: 1. Preparing and protecting EMS, hospital and primary health clinic staff. 2. Awareness and dissemination of key public health messages and psychosocial support. 3. Provision of 15000 food parcels to vulnerable families including labourers returning from Israel. 4. Ensure the wellbeing and coverage of basic needs of vulnerable families especially those with People with Disabilities between its members. 5. Provide PSS to families and awareness for violence prevention. 6. Provide NCD medicines for vulnerable chronic patients, unable to move because of the lockdown/curfew.

title.narrative: Other - People reached
People reached
Support to the COVID-19 response plan of the Palestine Red Crescent in Lebanon.

description.narrative:
From their mandate, PRCS/L enjoys full acceptance, respect and access within the areas under their jurisdiction, providing services in the Palestinian camps and its outskirts. With regard to their COVID-19 response plan, PRCS/L is the main coordinating actor between Palestinian factions and stakeholders in Lebanon, and they are working closely together with the Lebanese Red Cross. LRCS and PRCS/L have set-up protocols for transportation of COVID-19 cases (agreed with PLO, Palestinian embassy, UNRWA and other Palestinian authorities within the camps). This means PRCS/L will facilitate access to LRCS ambulances inside the camps for transportations. PRCS/L themselves have 17 ambulances and their EMS staff and volunteers will be trained by Emergency Medical Teams of LRCS, in case PRCS has to start doing quarantined transportations. Currently the focus is on containment, working risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) activities within the camps, informing people about the importance of screening, isolation and treatment, and ensuring that in close coordination with LRCS and UNWRA suspected patients are transported to the designated hospitals outside the camps.
An epidemic outbreak within the camps would go beyond the capacity of PRCS/L. If this would happen, PRCS/L could use their 5 hospitals as treatment places, isolating and designating an area of the hospital for monitoring and treatment of moderate COVID-19 cases. At the same time, PRCS/L will continue RCCE activities in the communities on handwashing, social distancing, recognising symptoms and home-based care.
Lebanon
Palestine Red Crescent in Lebanon and Netherlands Red Cross
Support to the COVID-19 response plan of the Palestine Red Crescent in Lebanon.

The Lebanon branch of the Palestine Red Crescent (PRCS/L) is the only mandated secondary health care service provider for the 500.000 Palestinian refugees living in Lebanon, and they are facing extreme challenges to maintain the delivery of these mandated services. UNRWA used to be one of the main donors of PRCS/L, covering 85% of the costs of patient referrals to the 5 hospitals PRCS/L is running. However, due to funding challenges UNWRA on 1 March officially communicated to PRCS/L that they will reduce the coverage of these referrals to a minimum. This has a massive impact on the ability of PRCS/L to sustain the life-saving services provided in their 5 hospitals.
The current economic crisis in Lebanon is exacerbating the already vulnerable financial situation of PRCS/L; with an unpegged exchange rate and the capacity of suppliers deteriorating, not being able to maintain bid validity at government rate, the capacity of PRCS/L to sustain the regular supply of consumables and life-saving equipment to their hospitals is impeded heavily.

title.narrative: Strengthening URCS COVID-19 preparedness and respone for effective risk mitigation and detection to control the spread of COVID-19 in high risk border districts.

description.narrative: Border districts of Busia, Tororo (Malaba), Rakai (Mutukula), Amuru (Elegu), Ntungamo (Mirama Hills), Isingiro (Kikagati), Lamwo, Adjumani, Kasese, Bundibugyo, Ntoroko, Kisoro and Kanungu.
People crossing border points and local communities living near the border points.

The whole country is at risk of COVID-19 outbreak, but the national taskforce has listed 42 districts along the borders and those along the truck routes as category 1: high risk and they have been prioritized for response interventions.

To strengthen the existing URCS COVID-19 preparedness and response structures and mechanisms to implement timely and effective risk mitigation, detection and response measures to control spread of COVID-19 in high risk border districts.

• Conduct risk communication, social mobilization, community engagement and accountability to communities along the border in 3 border districts of Ntungamo, Lamwo and Adjumani • Conduct screening and risk communication at 3 border entry points (Mirama Hills in Ntungamo; Ngom oromo and Madi opei in Lamwo). • Provide PPE for the volunteers and IPC supplies at the 3 POE and the community along these borders including quarantine centers. • Provide WASH equipment and supplies. Set up of handwashing points will be supported through provision of tippy taps, soap and hand washing demonstrations by the volunteers. • Enhance capacity of URCS to be able to prevent, prepare and respond to COVID-19.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response Haiti

description.narrative: NLRC & HRC

Prevent and reduce the risk of transmission of COVID-19 through effective coordination, implementation of preventative measures and the dissemination of basic information to local communities by mobilizing the Haitian Red Cross volunteer network. This project is aimed at achieving the following results: 1. The operational capacity of the various state and non-state institutions involved in the COVID-19 response in the target municipalities is strengthened through enhanced coordination and the implementation of preventative measures. 2. Public awareness on COVID-19 is increased through risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) activities. 3. The response capacities of Haitian Red Cross and other institutions in the target municipalities are strengthened through the reactivation of the Community Based Epidemiological Surveillance system (SEBAC) and the training of volunteers and staff.
Sud and Sud-Est department
The Covid-19 response project in Haiti, funded by MoFA through the DRU.

To implement Covid-19 response activities in Haiti. A significant increase in the number of COVID-19 cases is expected from mid-April onwards. The combination of COVID-19, the ongoing political and socioeconomic crisis and the upcoming cyclonic season, unfortunately paint a very grim picture for the people in Haiti for the months ahead.

Covid-19 response in Benin

description.narrative: Benin Red Cross and Netherlands Red Cross

Benin recorded its first case of COVID-19 on March 16, 2020 in Cotonou. Since then, despite the state’s measures to halt the spread of the pandemic, new confirmed cases have been recorded. The vast majority of cases are concentrated in the southern and most populous part of the country. The government is aware of the gravity of this pandemic and of the importance of the WHO directives concerning containment and mass screening. However, the government lacks the means to implement all the WHO recommendations and relies on the responsibility of the populations to respect and abide by the government measures. Yet, despite awareness campaigns carried out by the government, compliance with the measures remains problematic because of language barriers, the lack of access to conventional media (TV and radio) and social networks. In addition, understanding and abiding to the measures is often very challenging for a population reliant on the informal sector to ensure their livelihoods.
Many challenges lie ahead in terms of epidemiological surveillance of the virus within the communities; stigma, non-compliance with the government measures, fear of the population, rumors, and disinformation. Gender may impact the way in which health messaging can be distributed and be taken up. This needs to be addressed with dissemination of health information of the authorities to the population and psychosocial support to the first responders, volunteers, and vulnerable groups. Communication at the community level must be reinforced, as well as community-based surveillance. And because of the existing teams for contact monitoring and psychosocial support of the Benin Red Cross, the government requested specific expertise in these areas.
Benin

The overall objective of this operation is to contribute to the prevention and reduction of the immediate risks associated with the spread of COVID-19 in Benin by mobilizing the Benin Red Cross volunteer network.

The project is aimed at achieving the following results:
Result area 1: Community based surveillance systems vis-à-vis COVID-19 are strengthened by the Benin Red Cross 1) The population adopts preventive hygiene practices to control the rate of covid-19 infections and rumors are minimized 2) The community-based monitoring of the local health system is reinforced by volunteers of the Benin Red Cross
Result area 2: Benin Red Cross provides relevant response activities for those affected by COVID-19 1) Contaminated spaces identified are effectively disinfected 2) Benin Red Cross assists with safe burial practices 3) Benin Red Cross is ready to provide psychosocial support to people infected and affected by COVID-19
Result area 3: Reinforcement of the intervention capacity of Benin Red Cross in prevention and response to COVID-19 1) Appropriate measures are taken to protect staff and volunteers 2) Benin Red Cross has adequate human and material resources for operations management 3) The response is continuously monitored and evaluated

Covid-19 Response Malawi

description.narrative: 6 districts out of the 28 in total, including Lilongwe.
MRCS, NLRC, DRC, FRC

The aim of the Red Cross Movement Covid19 Preparedness and Responds Project is to enable Malawi Red Cross Society (MRCS) being well prepared and ready to respond to Covid19 preventing the onset of the disease and contributing to control mechanisms to prevent spread of the disease at all levels in Malawi.

The objective is to support the Red Cross Movement Covid19 Preparedness and Response Plan with funding channeled through the Danish Red Cross (DRC), who is leading the consortium. The project focuses on health; specifically on raising of awareness and enhancement of knowledge of key aspects of COVID-19 and equipping MRCS staff, volunteers and stakeholders. Furthermore, the sensitization and mobilization of at risk communities on prevention and control measures. In addition MRCS capacity is strengthened to support government infrastructure and services related to COVID-19.

Till this date there are 33 confirmed cases of which 22 in Lilongwe and with a total death toll of 3. This project will in high risk areas make use of scenario 2 such as Lilongwe and elsewhere scenario 1 with a scale up to level 3 when and if needed.

Lebanese Red Cross' response to the COVID-19 pandemic in Lebanon

description.narrative: 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) is a virus identified as the cause of an outbreak of respiratory illness first detected in Wuhan, China. Early on, many of the patients in the outbreak in Wuhan, China reportedly had some link to a large seafood and animal market, suggesting animal-to-person spread. However, a growing number of patients reportedly have not had exposure to animal markets, indicating person-to-person spread is occurring. At this time, it’s unclear how easily or sustainably this virus is spreading between people. Following the outbreak of 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) and after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak as a global emergency on January 31, 2020, national and international efforts has been made to ensure proper preparedness and response.
Lebanese Red Cross and Netherlands Red Cross
Lebanon
Response of the Lebanese Red Cross to the COVID-19 pandemic

Strategic Objectives: 1. Support in risk communication, community engagement and public awareness; 2. Support in case detection and identification at level dispatch; 3. Ensure safe and efficient transportation of suspected and confirmed cases; 4. Maintain provision of LRCS services to beneficiaries in a safe and effective manner while ensuring the safety of LRCS staff and volunteers
